content.subject: The standard astrogrid naming authority
content.description: This authority ID will be used to identify generic resources related to the Astrogrid consortium

content.subject: Galexev
content.description: GALAXEV is a library of evolutionary stellar population synthesis models computed using the new isochrone synthesis code of Bruzual and Charlot (2003). This code allows one to computes the spectral evolution of stellar populations in wide ranges of ages and metallicities at a resolution of 3 � across the whole wavelength range from 3200 � to 9500 �, and at lower resolution outside this range.

ns1:ParameterDefinition.name: OTHERMAGS
ns1:ParameterDefinition.ns8:UI_Description: mags and colours with more filter sets

ns1:ParameterDefinition.name: ABMAG
ns1:ParameterDefinition.ns23:UI_Description: AB magnitudes in SDSS filters as function of galaxy Age

ns1:ParameterDefinition.name: VEGAMAGS
ns1:ParameterDefinition.ns28:UI_Description: mags and colors (Vega) as function of galaxy Age in standard filters

content.subject: Pegase
content.description: PEGASE is a code which computes the spectral evolution of galaxies. The evolution of the stars, gas and metals is computed according to user selected star formation laws and initial stellar mass function. The stellar evolutionary tracks extend from the main sequence to the white dwarf stage. The emission of the gas in HII regions is also taken into account. The effect of extinction by dust is also modelled using a radiative transfer code.

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: GLOBALEXTINCTION
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns50:UI_Description: 0: No extinction 1: Extinction for a spheroidal geometry 2: Extinction for a disk geometry: inclination-averaged 3: Extinction for a disk geometry: specific inclination

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: SNMODEL
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns60:UI_Description: model A, B or C of Woosley & Weaver

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: FRACSUB
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns65:UI_Description: Mass fraction of substellar objects formed (real in [0.,1.])

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: CONEVOL
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns75:UI_Description: Consistent evolution of the stellar metallicity (y/n)?

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: INFALLMETAL
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns80:UI_Description: Metallicity of the infalling gas (mass fraction, real in [0.,1.])

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: IMF
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns100:UI_Description: 1: IMF_Kennicutt.dat 2: IMF_Kroupa.dat 3: IMF_MillerScalo.dat 4: IMF_Salpeter.dat 5: IMF_Scalo86.dat 6: IMF_Scalo98.dat 7: lognormal IMF 8: Rana & Basu (1992) 9: Ferrini (1991)

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: METALICITY
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns105:UI_Description: Metallicity (mass fraction) of the ISM at t=0 (real in [0.,1.])

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: GALWINDAGE
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns110:UI_Description: Age of the galactic winds (Myr, real)

ns33:ParameterDefinition.name: SFSCENARIO
ns33:ParameterDefinition.ns115:UI_Description: Type of star formation scenario? -2: file giving the SFR and the metallicity -1: file giving the SFR 0: instantaneous burst 1: SFR=p1 from t=0 to p2 2: SFR=p2*exp(-t/p1)/p1 3: SFR=(Mgas^p1)/p2 10 or more: code of the SFR law you have implemented in "spectra.f"

content.subject: SExtractor
content.description: SExtractor is a program that builds a catalogue of objects from an astronomical image. Although it is particularly oriented towards reduction of large scale galaxy-survey data, it performs rather well on moderately crowded star fields.

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: CATALOG_NAME
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns137:UI_Description: The catalogue of images derived from the input images

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: MASK_TYPE
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns147:UI_Description: type of detection MASKing: can be one of "NONE", "BLANK" or "CORRECT"

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: PIXEL_SCALE
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns187:UI_Description: size of pixel in arcsec (0=use FITS WCS info)

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: IMAGE_BAND
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns202:UI_Description: The input image measuerment band. This is used to form the column name in the output VOTable for the measured photometry.

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: PARAMETERS_NAME
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns222:UI_Description: A File containing the list of catalogue paramters that should be computed

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: config_file
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns227:UI_Description: File containing the main configuration parameters for SExtractor

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: DETECT_MINAREA
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns242:UI_Description: minimum number of pixels above threshold

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: DetectionImage
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns262:UI_Description: The image that is used to detect sources. Basic position, shape and size informtaion is derived from this image

ns135:ParameterDefinition.name: PhotoImage
ns135:ParameterDefinition.ns272:UI_Description: The Image that is used to measure photometric parameters

content.subject: BPZ
content.description: The software below implements the Bayesian photometric redshift method described in Benitez 2000 .

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: PROBS_LITE
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns294:UI_Description: Save only the final probability distribution

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: PROBS
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns319:UI_Description: Save all the galaxy probability distributions (very large file created)

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: EXCLUDE
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns329:UI_Description: Filters to be excluded from the estimation

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: CHECK
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns349:UI_Description: Perform some checks, compare observed colors with templates, etc.

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: ONLY_TYPE
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns359:UI_Description: Use spectroscopic redshifts instead of photo-z

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: NEW_AB
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns369:UI_Description: If yes, generate new AB files even if they already exist

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: ODDS
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns374:UI_Description: Odds threshold: affects confidence limits definition

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: VERBOSE
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns379:UI_Description: Print estimated redshifts to the standard output

ns292:ParameterDefinition.name: INTERP
ns292:ParameterDefinition.ns384:UI_Description: Number of interpolated templates between each of the original ones

content.subject: HyperZ
content.description: We refer to the paper Photometric Redshifts based on standard SED fitting procedures M. Bolzonella, J.-M. Miralles, R. Pell�, 2000, A and A 363, 476-492

ns411:ParameterDefinition.name: input_catalog
ns411:ParameterDefinition.ns423:UI_Description: The input catalogue of measured magnitude

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: matches
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns450:UI_Description: The VOTable file containing the sources to match

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: output
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns455:UI_Description: This can be one of HTML VOTable of Ascii, with the default being VOTable

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: merged_output
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns460:UI_Description: The VOTable file containing result of the match

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: maxMatches
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns464:UI_Name: maximum number of matches per target
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns465:UI_Description: maximum number of matches per target

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: targets
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns470:UI_Description: The VOTable file containing the target sources

content.subject: SWarp
content.description: SWarp is a program that resamples and co-adds together FITS images using any arbitrary astrometric projection defined in the WCS standard.

ns486:ParameterDefinition.name: IMAGEOUT_NAME
ns486:ParameterDefinition.ns488:UI_Description: The resampled and possibly coadded output image

ns486:ParameterDefinition.name: config_file
ns486:ParameterDefinition.ns493:UI_Description: File containing the main configuration parameters for Swarp

ns486:ParameterDefinition.name: Image
ns486:ParameterDefinition.ns498:UI_Description: The image that is used to detect sources. Basic position, shape and size informtaion is derived from this image

content.subject: HyperZ
content.description: We refer to the paper Photometric Redshifts based on standard SED fitting procedures M. Bolzonella, J.-M. Miralles, R. Pell�, 2000, A and A 363, 476-492

ns411:ParameterDefinition.name: input_catalog
ns411:ParameterDefinition.ns423:UI_Description: The input catalogue of measured magnitude

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: matches
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns450:UI_Description: The VOTable file containing the sources to match

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: output
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns455:UI_Description: This can be one of HTML VOTable of Ascii, with the default being VOTable

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: merged_output
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns460:UI_Description: The VOTable file containing result of the match

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: maxMatches
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns464:UI_Name: maximum number of matches per target
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns465:UI_Description: maximum number of matches per target

ns448:ParameterDefinition.name: targets
ns448:ParameterDefinition.ns470:UI_Description: The VOTable file containing the target sources

content.subject: SWarp
content.description: SWarp is a program that resamples and co-adds together FITS images using any arbitrary astrometric projection defined in the WCS standard.

ns486:ParameterDefinition.name: IMAGEOUT_NAME
ns486:ParameterDefinition.ns488:UI_Description: The resampled and possibly coadded output image

ns486:ParameterDefinition.name: config_file
ns486:ParameterDefinition.ns493:UI_Description: File containing the main configuration parameters for Swarp

ns486:ParameterDefinition.name: Image
ns486:ParameterDefinition.ns498:UI_Description: The image that is used to detect sources. Basic position, shape and size informtaion is derived from this image

content.subject: Starburst 99
content.description: Starburst99 is a web based software and data package designed to model spectrophotometric and related properties of star-forming galaxies.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: LMAX
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns505:UI_Description: LMIN and LMAX are the indices of the evolutionary tracks, sorted by mass. Normally you do not want to mess with the variable and leave it at 0. However, if you want to track down some peculiarity of the output, you may want to compute the parameters for only one track. For instance, specifying 21,21 indicates that only a 100 M star should by used, and everything else is suppressed. The cross-ID's between index and mass are at the bottom of the input file. The example here refers to JMG=1 or 2. For JMG=0, you would have chosen 5,5. This does not apply to JMG=3 since the mass grid is variable and LMIN, LMAX are not used.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: LMIN
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns510:UI_Description: LMIN and LMAX are the indices of the evolutionary tracks, sorted by mass. Normally you do not want to mess with the variable and leave it at 0. However, if you want to track down some peculiarity of the output, you may want to compute the parameters for only one track. For instance, specifying 21,21 indicates that only a 100 M star should by used, and everything else is suppressed. The cross-ID's between index and mass are at the bottom of the input file. The example here refers to JMG=1 or 2. For JMG=0, you would have chosen 5,5. This does not apply to JMG=3 since the mass grid is variable and LMIN, LMAX are not used.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: UPMA
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns540:UI_Description: upper mass limit for the IMF.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: ALPHA
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns545:UI_Description: IMF exponent. A power law is assumed.(2.35 = SALPETER):

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: SFR
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns549:UI_Name: SFR [SOLAR MASSES PER YEAR] IF 'CONT. SF' IS CHOSEN:
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns550:UI_Description: the star formation rate (only used for a continuous rate). The total accumulated mass is spread out between the upper and lower cut-off masses.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: TOMA
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns554:UI_Name: TOTAL STELLAR MASS [10^6 SOLAR MASSES] IF 'FIXED MASS' IS CHOSEN
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns555:UI_Description: this is the total stellar mass (spread out between the upper and lower cut-off masses). It is only used if an instantaneous burst is specified.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: TMAX
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns560:UI_Description: [1.e6 YEARS]: the oldest age of the model.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: SNCUT
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns570:UI_Description: stars with ZAMS masses of 8 M and higher form supernovae. This is the suggested standard value but can be modified if desired.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: STEP
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns575:UI_Description: [1.e6 years] this is the timestep used for the calculations. It is a very important parameter. On the one hand, the computing time scales with STEP, so you want to avoid too high resolution, but on the other, short evolutionary phases can be missed. 0.1 (i.e. 10e5 yr) is a good value if you use full isochrone synthesis. If full isochrone synthesis is not used, 0.1 or larger is suggested only for tests --- be aware that WR or RSG numbers are no longer properly calculated for a STEP of 0.1 unless full isochrone synthesis is selected!

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: ISF
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns584:UI_Name: CONTINUOUS STAR FORMATION (>0) OR FIXED MASS (<=0)
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns585:UI_Description: if this is a negative integer, star formation is instantaneous, otherwise it is continuous.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: JMG
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns594:UI_Name: SMALL (=0) OR LARGE (=1) MASS GRID; ISOCHRONE ON LARGE GRID (=2) OR FULL ISOCHRONE (=3):
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns595:UI_Description: these are four options for the interpolation in mass. They are explained in the code. Shortly: 0 -- evolutionary synthesis with a mass resolution of 5 M (only recommended for tests); 1 -- same as 0, but with a resolution of 1 M. This method was used in Leitherer & Heckman (1995); 2 -- isochrone synthesis with a fixed mass resolution of 1 M; 3 -- isochrone synthesis with a variable mass grid. This is the fanciest method and is the recommended mode.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: TDEL
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns600:UI_Description: [1.e6YR] the file containing the output spectrum can be pretty big. This parameter controls the time step to print out the spectrum. This is independent of the time resolution -- only the print out is affected! 1 Myr is usually a good value but if you compute the starburst up to 100 Myr, you may prefer TDEL=5 Myr unless you have many Gb of disk space.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: DOMA
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns605:UI_Description: lower mass limit for the IMF.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: IZ
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns610:UI_Description: 92-94 STD. MASS-LOSS: 11=0.001; 12=0.004; 13=0.008; 14=0.020; 15=0.040 92-94 HIGH MASS-LOSS: 21=0.001; 22=0.004; 23=0.008; 24=0.020; 25=0.040 24 -- this integer indicates the evolutionary tracks to be used. The choices are 11-15 or 21-25, where the former select one of five metallicities with the standard tracks, and the latter do the same for the high mass-loss tracks. Example: "23" selects 40% solar metallicity with the high mass loss tracks.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: IVT
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns615:UI_Description: atmospheric parameters used for the spectral features in the near-IR. Detailed explanations are in the sp-feature subroutine. Defaults are 3,0, i.e. microturbulent velocities of 3 km/sec and solar abundance ratios for alpha-element/Fe

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: BHCUT
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns635:UI_Description: stars with ZAMS masses of 120 M and lower form supernovae. An alternative scenario would be to let stars above a certain threshold form a black hole. For instance, BHCUT=40. results in SNe only from the mass range 40 to 8 M.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: TIME1
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns640:UI_Description: [1.E6 YEARS] the epoch of the onset of the star formation. In almost all cases you want this to be close to 0. It should not be exactly 0 for numerical reasons. 0.01 (i.e. 10e4 yr) is a good number.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: IRSG
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns645:UI_Description: atmospheric parameters used for the spectral features in the near-IR. Detailed explanations are in the sp-feature subroutine. Defaults are 3,0, i.e. microturbulent velocities of 3 km/sec and solar abundance ratios for alpha-element/Fe

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: ILINE
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns649:UI_Name: METALLICITY OF THE UV LINE SPECTRUM:
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns650:UI_Description: 1=SOLAR, 2=LMC/SMC) [ILINE] 1 -- a switch for the choice of the UV spectral library. This switch applies to both the FUSE and the HST/IUE libraries. It is independent of the metallicity of the tracks/atmospheres. Normally one would use ILINE=1 with IZ=24 and ILINE=2 with IZ=22.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: IWIND
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns655:UI_Description: (0=MAEDER; 1=EMP.; 2=THEOR.; 3=ELSON; 4=UCL): [IWIND] 2 -- this selects the wind model to be used for the calculation of the wind power. The four models are discussed in ApJ, 401, 498 (1992) and in Smith et al. (2002). "2" is the suggested default parameter.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: IATMOS
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns675:UI_Description: 1=PLA,2=LEJ,3=LEJ+SCH,4=LEJ+HIL,5=PAU+HIL [IATMOS] 5 -- this is the choice of the model atmosphere. 1 is a bare-bone version with black bodies, good only for tests. 2 uses the Kurucz models as compiled by Lejeune for all stars. 3 uses Lejeune for stars with plane-parallel atmospheres and Schmutz for stars with strong winds. 4 uses Lejeune, but replaces the Schmutz by the Hillier atmospheres. 5 is like 4, except for the O atmospheres, for which we use the Pauldrach models. 5 is the recommended value.

ns503:ParameterDefinition.name: NAME
ns503:ParameterDefinition.ns690:UI_Description: any identifier you want to assign to the model. You will find it in the header of each output file.

content.subject: JBORealCEC
content.description: A Commandline Execution Controller that will run most of the applications that Astrogrid has configured/wrapped so far.

cea:ParameterDefinition.name: Query
cea:ParameterDefinition.ceapd:UI_Description: Astronomy Data Query Language that defines the search criteria

cea:ParameterDefinition.name: Format
cea:ParameterDefinition.ceapd:UI_Description: How the results are to be returned. VOTABLE or CSV for now
